Use alcohol‑based hand rub as the preferred method after care
Use a dedicated stethoscope/blood pressure cuff for the client when possible
Clean high‑touch surfaces using a sporicidal disinfectant per policy
Discontinue isolation once stools are formed for 24 hours
answer: Clean high‑touch surfaces using a sporicidal disinfectant per policy
Perform hand hygiene with soap and water after removing gloves
Use a dedicated stethoscope/blood pressure cuff for the client when possible
rationale: C. difficile forms spores. Soap-and-water removes spores better than alcohol rubs. Dedicated equipment and sporicidal cleaning reduce transmission. Stopping isolation follows facility policy, not just 24 hours of formed stools.

choice_rationales.Use alcohol‑based hand rub as the prefer: Incorrect—alcohol is less effective against spores.
choice_rationales.Clean high‑touch surfaces using a sporic: Correct—spores persist on surfaces; sporicidal agent needed.

stem: A nurse is caring for a client with MRSA wound drainage requiring contact precautions. Which actions are appropriate? (Select all that apply.)
choices: Don gown and gloves upon room entry
Use dedicated or disposable equipment when possible
Perform hand hygiene before and after care
Wear an N95 respirator for routine care
Leave PPE on when exiting to save time
answer: Don gown and gloves upon room entry
Perform hand hygiene before and after care
Use dedicated or disposable equipment when possible
rationale: Contact precautions require gown and gloves with careful hand hygiene and dedicated equipment. N95 is not required for contact precautions. PPE must be removed before exiting to avoid contaminating hallways.

choice_rationales.Leave PPE on when exiting to save time: Incorrect—PPE must be removed before exit.

stem: A nurse is caring for a client with influenza requiring droplet precautions. Which actions are appropriate? (Select all that apply.)
choices: Wear a surgical mask when within 3–6 feet of the client (per policy)
Place the client in a private room if possible
Have the client wear a mask during transport
Wear an N95 respirator for all care
Keep the door closed at all times to maintain negative pressure
answer: Have the client wear a mask during transport
Place the client in a private room if possible
Wear a surgical mask when within 3–6 feet of the client (per policy)
rationale: Droplet precautions typically require a surgical mask within close range, private room if possible, and masking the client for transport. Negative-pressure room and N95 are not routine for droplet precautions unless aerosol-generating procedures require it.

choice_rationales.Wear an N95 respirator for all care: Incorrect—N95 not routinely required for droplet precautions.
choice_rationales.Keep the door closed at all times to mai: Incorrect—negative pressure is for airborne precautions.

case.case_study: A 68-year-old client is admitted with shortness of breath and weakness. Past history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes.
nurse_actions: Applied oxygen at 2 L/min via nasal cannula

stem: Which findings are consistent with hypokalemia? (Select all that apply.)
choices: Muscle weakness
Peaked T waves on ECG
Irregular heart rhythm
Constipation
Hyperactive bowel sounds
answer: Muscle weakness
Irregular heart rhythm
Constipation
rationale: Hypokalemia can cause muscle weakness, constipation/ileus, and dysrhythmias. Peaked T waves are more consistent with hyperkalemia; bowel sounds are often decreased.

case.case_study: A 68-year-old client is admitted with shortness of breath and weakness. Past history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes.
nurse_actions: Applied oxygen at 2 L/min via nasal cannula

stem: A client has had prolonged vomiting. ABGs: pH 7.50, PaCO2 44, HCO3− 34. How should the nurse interpret this?
choices: Respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic alkalosis
Respiratory acidosis
Metabolic acidosis
answer: Metabolic alkalosis
rationale: Alkalemia with elevated bicarbonate indicates metabolic alkalosis, commonly due to loss of gastric acid from vomiting.

choice_rationales.Respiratory acidosis: Would have low pH and high PaCO2.
choice_rationales.Metabolic acidosis: Would have low pH and low HCO3−.

stem: A nurse is caring for a client with active pulmonary TB requiring airborne precautions. Which actions are appropriate? (Select all that apply.)
choices: Wear an N95 respirator (fit-tested) before entering the room
Place the client in a negative-pressure room if available
Keep the door closed except for entry/exit
Use a surgical mask instead of an N95 for routine care
Remove the respirator after leaving the room and closing the door
answer: Keep the door closed except for entry/exit
Place the client in a negative-pressure room if available
Remove the respirator after leaving the room and closing the door
Wear an N95 respirator (fit-tested) before entering the room
rationale: Airborne precautions require a negative-pressure room and an N95 respirator. Door should remain closed. PPE is removed after exit (following policy) to prevent exposure. A surgical mask is not sufficient for airborne pathogens.

choice_rationales.Use a surgical mask instead of an N95 fo: Incorrect—surgical masks do not filter airborne particles like N95.
choice_rationales.Remove the respirator after leaving the: Correct—prevents inhalation during exit per policy sequence.

stem: A client is prescribed nitroglycerin sublingual (SL) for chest pain. Which instructions should the nurse include? (Select all that apply.)
choices: Sit down before taking the medication
Take one tablet and repeat every 5 minutes up to 3 doses if pain persists
Store tablets in a dark glass container and keep tightly closed
Drive yourself to the clinic if pain is relieved after one dose
Call emergency services if pain persists after the first dose per local policy
answer: Sit down before taking the medication
Take one tablet and repeat every 5 minutes up to 3 doses if pain persists
Store tablets in a dark glass container and keep tightly closed
Call emergency services if pain persists after the first dose per local policy
rationale: Nitroglycerin can cause hypotension; sitting prevents syncope. Standard teaching includes 1 tab q5 min up to 3 doses, proper storage, and activating EMS if pain persists (often after first dose).

choice_rationales.Drive yourself to the clinic if pain is: Incorrect—do not drive during/after possible MI; activate emergency plan.
choice_rationales.Call emergency services if pain persists: Correct—persistent pain may indicate MI; EMS is safest.

stem: Which findings are consistent with hypokalemia? (Select all that apply.)

Constipation
Hyperactive bowel sounds
answer: Muscle weakness

rationale: Hypokalemia can cause muscle weakness, constipation/ileus, and dysrhythmias. Peaked T waves are more consistent with hyperkalemia; bowel sounds are often decreased.

stem: A client has had prolonged vomiting. ABGs: pH 7.50, PaCO2 44, HCO3− 34. How should the nurse interpret this?
choices: Respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic alkalosis
Respiratory acidosis
Metabolic acidosis
answer: Metabolic alkalosis
rationale: Alkalemia with elevated bicarbonate indicates metabolic alkalosis, commonly due to loss of gastric acid from vomiting.

choice_rationales.Respiratory acidosis: Would have low pH and high PaCO2.
choice_rationales.Metabolic acidosis: Would have low pH and low HCO3−.

stem: A nurse is caring for a client with C. difficile requiring contact precautions. Which actions are appropriate? (Select all that apply.)
choices: Perform hand hygiene with soap and water after removing gloves
Use alcohol‑based hand rub as the preferred method after care
Use a dedicated stethoscope/blood pressure cuff for the client when possible
Clean high‑touch surfaces using a sporicidal disinfectant per policy
Discontinue isolation once stools are formed for 24 hours
answer: Clean high‑touch surfaces using a sporicidal disinfectant per policy
Perform hand hygiene with soap and water after removing gloves
Use a dedicated stethoscope/blood pressure cuff for the client when possible
rationale: C. difficile forms spores. Soap-and-water removes spores better than alcohol rubs. Dedicated equipment and sporicidal cleaning reduce transmission. Stopping isolation follows facility policy, not just 24 hours of formed stools.

choice_rationales.Use alcohol‑based hand rub as the prefer: Incorrect—alcohol is less effective against spores.
choice_rationales.Clean high‑touch surfaces using a sporic: Correct—spores persist on surfaces; sporicidal agent needed.

stem: A client is prescribed nitroglycerin sublingual (SL) for chest pain. Which instructions should the nurse include? (Select all that apply.)

Take one tablet and repeat every 5 minutes up to 3 doses if pain persists

answer: Sit down before taking the medication
Take one tablet and repeat every 5 minutes up to 3 doses if pain persists
Store tablets in a dark glass container and keep tightly closed
Call emergency services if pain persists after the first dose per local policy
rationale: Nitroglycerin can cause hypotension; sitting prevents syncope. Standard teaching includes 1 tab q5 min up to 3 doses, proper storage, and activating EMS if pain persists (often after first dose).

stem: A nurse is caring for a client with C. difficile requiring contact precautions. Which actions are appropriate? (Select all that apply.)
choices: Perform hand hygiene with soap and water after removing gloves

Use a dedicated stethoscope/blood pressure cuff for the client when possible

choice_rationales.Clean high‑touch surfaces using a sporic: Correct—spores persist on surfaces; sporicidal agent needed.

stem: Which findings are consistent with hypokalemia? (Select all that apply.)

Peaked T waves on ECG
Irregular heart rhythm

choice_rationales.Respiratory acidosis: Would have low pH and high PaCO2.
choice_rationales.Metabolic acidosis: Would have low pH and low HCO3−.

stem: A client has had prolonged vomiting. ABGs: pH 7.50, PaCO2 44, HCO3− 34. How should the nurse interpret this?
choices: Respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic alkalosis
Respiratory acidosis
Metabolic acidosis
answer: Metabolic alkalosis
rationale: Alkalemia with elevated bicarbonate indicates metabolic alkalosis, commonly due to loss of gastric acid from vomiting.

choice_rationales.Respiratory acidosis: Would have low pH and high PaCO2.
choice_rationales.Metabolic acidosis: Would have low pH and low HCO3−.

case.case_study: A 68-year-old client is admitted with shortness of breath and weakness. Past history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes.
nurse_actions: Applied oxygen at 2 L/min via nasal cannula

stem: A client is prescribed nitroglycerin sublingual (SL) for chest pain. Which instructions should the nurse include? (Select all that apply.)
choices: Sit down before taking the medication
Take one tablet and repeat every 5 minutes up to 3 doses if pain persists
Store tablets in a dark glass container and keep tightly closed
Drive yourself to the clinic if pain is relieved after one dose
Call emergency services if pain persists after the first dose per local policy
answer: Sit down before taking the medication
Take one tablet and repeat every 5 minutes up to 3 doses if pain persists
Store tablets in a dark glass container and keep tightly closed
Call emergency services if pain persists after the first dose per local policy
rationale: Nitroglycerin can cause hypotension; sitting prevents syncope. Standard teaching includes 1 tab q5 min up to 3 doses, proper storage, and activating EMS if pain persists (often after first dose).

choice_rationales.Drive yourself to the clinic if pain is: Incorrect—do not drive during/after possible MI; activate emergency plan.
choice_rationales.Call emergency services if pain persists: Correct—persistent pain may indicate MI; EMS is safest.

stem: A nurse is caring for a client with influenza requiring droplet precautions. Which actions are appropriate? (Select all that apply.)
choices: Wear a surgical mask when within 3–6 feet of the client (per policy)
Place the client in a private room if possible
Have the client wear a mask during transport
Wear an N95 respirator for all care
Keep the door closed at all times to maintain negative pressure
answer: Have the client wear a mask during transport
Place the client in a private room if possible
Wear a surgical mask when within 3–6 feet of the client (per policy)
rationale: Droplet precautions typically require a surgical mask within close range, private room if possible, and masking the client for transport. Negative-pressure room and N95 are not routine for droplet precautions unless aerosol-generating procedures require it.

choice_rationales.Wear an N95 respirator for all care: Incorrect—N95 not routinely required for droplet precautions.
choice_rationales.Keep the door closed at all times to mai: Incorrect—negative pressure is for airborne precautions.

stem: A nurse is caring for a client with MRSA wound drainage requiring contact precautions. Which actions are appropriate? (Select all that apply.)
choices: Don gown and gloves upon room entry
Use dedicated or disposable equipment when possible
Perform hand hygiene before and after care
Wear an N95 respirator for routine care
Leave PPE on when exiting to save time
answer: Don gown and gloves upon room entry
Perform hand hygiene before and after care
Use dedicated or disposable equipment when possible
rationale: Contact precautions require gown and gloves with careful hand hygiene and dedicated equipment. N95 is not required for contact precautions. PPE must be removed before exiting to avoid contaminating hallways.

choice_rationales.Leave PPE on when exiting to save time: Incorrect—PPE must be removed before exit.

stem: A client experiences IV antibiotic reaction and becomes pale/clammy with hypotension and tachycardia. Complete the bowtie.

middle_options: Slow infusion and reassess
Stop infusion, support airway/breathing, call rapid response/EMS per policy
Give oral fluids
Document only
bowtie.middle_answer: Stop infusion, support airway/breathing, call rapid response/EMS per policy
right_options: Improved wheeze after epinephrine per orders
bowtie.right_answer: Improved wheeze after epinephrine per orders

rationale: Rapid onset wheezing, facial swelling, and hypotension after a medication suggests anaphylaxis. Priority is stopping the agent and supporting ABCs; prepare epinephrine per protocol.

stem: A client experiences GI bleed and becomes pale/clammy with hypotension and tachycardia. Complete the bowtie.

middle_options: Restrict fluids
Lay supine, maintain airway, start large‑bore IV fluids per protocol, notify provider
Give diuretics
Delay until labs return
bowtie.middle_answer: Lay supine, maintain airway, start large‑bore IV fluids per protocol, notify provider

rationale: Acute blood loss decreases circulating volume leading to tachycardia, hypotension, cool clammy skin, and decreased urine output. Priority is ABCs and rapid fluid/blood support per protocol.

Encourage ambulation

Lay supine, maintain airway, start large‑bore IV fluids per protocol, notify provider
Give diuretics
Delay until labs return
bowtie.middle_answer: Lay supine, maintain airway, start large‑bore IV fluids per protocol, notify provider

rationale: Acute blood loss decreases circulating volume leading to tachycardia, hypotension, cool clammy skin, and decreased urine output. Priority is ABCs and rapid fluid/blood support per protocol.

stem: A post-op client on IV opioids is difficult to arouse and has RR 6/min. Complete the bowtie.

middle_options: Give another dose for uncontrolled pain
Stimulate the client, support airway/breathing, prepare naloxone per orders
Encourage ambulation
Offer oral fluids and reassess later
bowtie.middle_answer: Stimulate the client, support airway/breathing, prepare naloxone per orders

rationale: Bradypnea and decreased LOC after opioids indicate respiratory depression. Priority is airway/breathing support and naloxone per protocol while monitoring for rebound pain.

stem: A client experiences IV antibiotic reaction and becomes pale/clammy with hypotension and tachycardia. Complete the bowtie.

middle_options: Slow infusion and reassess
Stop infusion, support airway/breathing, call rapid response/EMS per policy
Give oral fluids
Document only
bowtie.middle_answer: Stop infusion, support airway/breathing, call rapid response/EMS per policy
right_options: Improved wheeze after epinephrine per orders
bowtie.right_answer: Improved wheeze after epinephrine per orders

rationale: Rapid onset wheezing, facial swelling, and hypotension after a medication suggests anaphylaxis. Priority is stopping the agent and supporting ABCs; prepare epinephrine per protocol.

case.case_study: A 68-year-old client is admitted with shortness of breath and weakness. Past history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes.
nurse_actions: Applied oxygen at 2 L/min via nasal cannula

case.case_study: A 68-year-old client is admitted with shortness of breath and weakness. Past history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes.
nurse_actions: Applied oxygen at 2 L/min via nasal cannula

stem: Based on the case information and vitals, which finding should the nurse address FIRST?
choices: SpO2 88% on room air
Temperature 99.8°F (37.7°C)
Client reports weakness
History of hypertension
answer: SpO2 88% on room air
rationale: Apply ABCs. Low oxygen saturation is an immediate threat to life; address oxygenation/ventilation first while continuing assessment.

choice_rationales.SpO2 88% on room air: Correct—hypoxemia threatens airway/breathing and requires immediate intervention.
choice_rationales.Temperature 99.8°F (37.7°C): Low-grade elevation is not the most immediate threat compared with hypoxemia.
choice_rationales.Client reports weakness: Important but not more urgent than oxygenation compromise.
choice_rationales.History of hypertension: Chronic condition; not the immediate priority in this moment.

case.case_study: A 68-year-old client is admitted with shortness of breath and weakness. Past history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes.
nurse_actions: Applied oxygen at 2 L/min via nasal cannula

stem: The nurse is initiating immediate interventions. Which action should the nurse NOT perform?
choices: Place the client in high‑Fowler’s position
Apply oxygen per protocol and reassess SpO2
Leave the client alone to gather supplies from the supply room
Notify the provider of persistent hypoxemia despite initial measures
answer: Leave the client alone to gather supplies from the supply room
rationale: A client with hypoxemia and signs of instability requires close monitoring. Do not leave the client unattended; delegate to obtain supplies if needed.

choice_rationales.Leave the client alone to gather supplie: Correct—unsafe to leave an unstable client unattended.
choice_rationales.Notify the provider of persistent hypoxe: Appropriate—escalation is needed if not improving.

case.case_study: A 68-year-old client is admitted with shortness of breath and weakness. Past history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes.
nurse_actions: Applied oxygen at 2 L/min via nasal cannula

stem: After implementing initial actions and receiving provider orders, which assessments are most important to trend? (Select all that apply.)
choices: Respiratory rate and work of breathing
SpO2 response to oxygen therapy
Urine output
Color of the client’s socks
Mental status/level of consciousness
answer: Respiratory rate and work of breathing
SpO2 response to oxygen therapy
Urine output
Mental status/level of consciousness
rationale: Trend indicators of oxygenation/ventilation and perfusion: RR/WOB, SpO2 response, urine output, and mental status. Sock color is non-clinical.

choice_rationales.Urine output: Correct—reflects perfusion and response to fluids/shock risk.
choice_rationales.Mental status/level of consciousness: Correct—worsening can signal hypoxemia or poor perfusion.

case.case_study: A 68-year-old client is admitted with shortness of breath and weakness. Past history includes hypertension and type 2 diabetes.
nurse_actions: Applied oxygen at 2 L/min via nasal cannula

stem: Complete the bowtie using the case information.

middle_options: Apply oxygen and reassess; escalate if not improving
Hold all fluids to prevent overload
Encourage ambulation immediately
Give a laxative PRN
bowtie.middle_answer: Apply oxygen and reassess; escalate if not improving
right_options: SpO2 increases and work of breathing decreases
bowtie.right_answer: SpO2 increases and work of breathing decreases

rationale: The case indicates hypoxemia (SpO2 88% RA) with increased RR. Prioritize oxygenation and reassessment; improvement is shown by better saturation and decreased work of breathing.
